The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. The axioms are also consistent with the standard mathematical theory of Hilbert spaces. We believe that this work provides a significant step toward a mathematical foundation for quantum theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we compare the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Less)

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has caused a global health crisis. The SARS-CoV-2 virus is able to evade the host immune response by blocking the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, which are key factors in the activation of the IFN pathway. In this study, we show that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this evasion mechanism. We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1, which is a key factor in the nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2. We also show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. In the male reproductive system, sperm cells are quiescent due to the inhibition of proton channels by zinc, but become active once introduced into the female reproductive tract, where zinc is low. How zinc inhibits proton channels is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of zinc inhibition of proton channels. We find that zinc binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the zinc-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how zinc inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet the needs of a growing population. This will be a challenge because the optimum growing temperature for maize is exceeded in many regions of the world. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase substantially. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption inferred from mean sequence relative read abundance ranged from >99% (plains zebra) to <1% (dik-dik). Grass RRA was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of % grass consumption, indicating that RRA conveys reliable quantitative information about consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study demonstrates the power of DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis, but most expect to remain in business for at least 6 mo. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. We also find that many small businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act loans. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is far less than expected, on the order of tens of thousands of tons. This is due to size-selective sinks, such as nano-fragmentation and sinking of microplastic particles. This sink may be of major importance in the fate of the missing plastic debris.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is a fundamental characteristic of life. In humans, this ability is limited by the mother’s metabolic power. In other species, this limit is imposed by resource availability. Here, we show that the ability to reproduce is also limited by the mother’s metabolic power in other placental mammals. We show that the increase in reproductive output that comes with domestication and the practice of allonursing is due to an increase in metabolic power rather than an increase in resource availability. Our results suggest that the metabolic power of the mother is the ultimate limit on reproductive output in placental mammals.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder with a high mortality rate. No treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process, and patients die within a few years after disease onset. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. We present here an in vivo proof of concept of the ability of the caspase-1 inhibitor prodrug VX-765 to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in proteolipid protein α-syn (PLP-SYN) mice, a transgenic mouse model of MSA. Our results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is also the first line of defense against pathogens and debris in the blood. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. This paper describes the nature of the communication system between these cells. The communication system is highly efficient and is able to rapidly and robustly transmit information throughout the endothelium. This is important for controlling the many functions of the endothelium. The communication system is also highly dynamic, allowing for the rapid and robust control of the endothelium in response to changes in the environment. This is important for maintaining homeostasis in the body. The communication system is a key feature of the endothelium and is essential for its function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of a data system that provides open access to a wide range of data on the COVID-19 pandemic, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance systems. These data are available through a simple API, and are updated daily. We provide examples of how these data can be used to track the pandemic, augmenting traditional public health reporting, and to empower research and decision-making. We hope that this system will be useful to researchers and policy makers in the United States and around the world.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as heart rate regulation, muscle contraction, and hormone secretion. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is essential for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is constantly changing in response to the environment and the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is still being investigated, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is influenced by the host and the environment. This study provides insight into the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to synthesize natural products that could be used as a source of therapeutics. The results of this study could lead to the discovery of new compounds that could be used to treat a variety of diseases.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, yet the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of becoming subordinate, directly influences social dominance in rats. We identified an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate exhibit reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens and are unable to produce ATP and ROS at the same level as low-anxious animals. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is of great importance for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) elastomers with distinct behaviors and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. To enhance programmability, the synthesized structures are heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of mechanical structures with desired responses. The hemoglobin system is a major target of developmental regulation. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of hemoglobin expression in humans. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is down-regulated in the adult bone marrow. In erythroid cells, IGF2BP1 is expressed at high levels and is required for the fetal-like expression of hemoglobin. We show that IGF2BP1 mediates posttranscriptional regulation of hemoglobin expression in erythroid cells. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This may have implications for the development of hemoglobinopathies and hemoglobin-based therapies. Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in cancer treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to therapy, and the survival rate remains low. In this study, we found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids. This resistance is mediated by the transcription factor sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), which is activated by the mTORC1-dependent induction of stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1). We also found that SREBP1/SCD1-mediated lipogenesis is a key mechanism of ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells. In addition, we found that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. This study provides a rationale for the development of combination therapies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most commonly used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs), which is associated with the up-regulation of the Ca2+ sensor protein STIM1. Our data indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of plasma membrane Ca2+ channels. Our findings may help to understand the mechanism of LCCBs action and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of heart failure. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal land. We show that the NWFP has not yet achieved its goals. The policy halted clearcutting on federal land, but this has so far been insufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the early-seral ecosystem area was stable, but declined in two ecoregions—the Coast Range and Cascades—along with early-seral bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the need for a more holistic approach to forest management that considers the full range of ecosystem services and values. This is particularly important in the context of climate change, where the role of forests in climate regulation and carbon sequestration is increasingly recognized.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We also show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results for the problem of semantic segmentation of satellite images. The code is available at https://github.com/s-y-s/dilated_conv.git.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin, reduces sleepiness, and phase-departs the circadian clock, all of which may contribute to the negative impact of this technology on sleep. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas impact event is a well-known episode in Earth history, but the cause of this event is still debated. One of the most popular hypotheses is that a bolide impact triggered the event. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the YDB samples is consistent with terrestrial sources. The Os in the spherules is likely derived from the same source.

CTLA-4 is a negative regulator of T cell activation, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. We found that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in both the thymus and periphery. CTLA-4 deletion in the thymus resulted in the development of autoimmunity in the periphery, whereas deletion in the periphery resulted in autoimmunity in the thymus. This indicates that CTLA-4 is required for both central and peripheral tolerance.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes (PCWDEs) obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of an arsenal of PCWDEs encoded in their genomes. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding PCW

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Less)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, but that the size of the population was more important than the number of models in the population. We also found that the greater variation participants had access to in the larger populations may have overwhelmed their working memory and weakened their ability to selectively copy the best-adapted plane(s). Our results suggest that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. This is an important finding for the design of future experiments and the study of CCE in general. (Abridged)

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE is a protein that is produced by astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain. We found that APOE is important for the ability of astrocytes to remove synapses that are no longer functional. APOE2 enhances the rate of synapse removal by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE is important for the accumulation of a protein that is a marker of senescent synapses in the brain. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytosis, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis may help to explain the increased risk of AD in APOE4 carriers.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of about 1,200 km. It is the densest part of the Earth, with a density of 13.0–13.5 g/cm3. The inner core is thought to have formed by the solidification of the core material. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, with the first step being the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. View Full-Text

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). Specifically, compared with controls, marijuana abusers had significantly attenuated brain DA responses to methylphenidate. In ventral striatum (key brain reward region), methylphenidate-induced reductions in DA responses were inversely correlated with addiction severity and craving. The attenuated responses to methylphenidate, including reduced decreases in striatal DA, are consistent with decreased brain reactivity to the DA stimulation in marijuana abusers that might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. These findings highlight the urgency to investigate effects of chronic marijuana in the human brain.

Language is the most complex cognitive ability known. Its neural mechanisms are therefore of great interest to neuroscience and cognitive science. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural network language models make accurate predictions about the brain’s responses to sentences, generalizing across different datasets and imaging modalities. We also find that the models’ neural fits correlate with their ability to predict which words will likely follow a given sentence in a continuous reading task. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the neural mechanisms of language comprehension in the human brain. They also suggest that the brain may use predictive processing to optimize language comprehension, perhaps by dynamically tuning the weights of its many competing computation pathways.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still an open question whether DL can be used in scientific computing, where the problems are often ill-conditioned and the data are often noisy. In this paper, we show that this is indeed the case. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This result implies a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the use of DL in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has become a textbook example of exponential growth. The first case was reported in China in December 2019, and the first death in Europe in January 2020. By the end of March 2020, the number of cases had grown exponentially, and the number of deaths had grown linearly. This pattern is well known, but it is also a classic example of a phenomenon that has been studied for decades: exponential growth is difficult to understand. In this paper, we discuss the classic experiment that is often cited as evidence for this phenomenon. We show that the experiment’s design is flawed, and that the conclusion drawn from it is not supported by the data.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and its history is intertwined with the development of modern medicine. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a new species of leprosy bacterium, which is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We found that this species is closely related to the leprosy bacterium that causes peripheral nervous system disease, and that both species are ancient descendants of a common ancestor. These findings suggest that the two leprosy species are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This study also provides a framework for the study of ancient leprosy species, which are important for understanding the history of leprosy and the evolution of the human genome. (Less)

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also the keystones of thermodynamics, which is the foundation of statistical mechanics. The interplay between these concepts is a central issue in the study of isolated quantum systems. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics of a quantum system is completely determined by the entanglement of its initial state. This result is a major step toward a complete understanding of the thermodynamics of isolated quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. However, the spike protein is a target for the virus, and mutations in it are expected to occur frequently. Therefore, it is important to develop vaccines that are able to protect against these mutations. Here, we describe a vaccine that is based on a segment of the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 that has been codon-pair deoptimized. This vaccine is able to protect hamsters from COVID-19 caused by the wild-type virus and is expected to be able to protect humans as well. This vaccine is expected to be able to protect against mutations in the spike protein. Therefore, it may be able to protect against future variants of SARS-CoV-2. This vaccine may be able to protect against COVID-19 caused by other coronaviruses as well. Therefore, it may be able to protect against future variants of other coronaviruses.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, with multiple transmission pathways. Today, most human plague cases are caused by inhalation of infectious droplets, but the historical spread of plague in Europe is poorly understood. Here, we present a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. Our model can be used to study the historical spread of plague in Europe and other regions. It can also be used to study the impact of vector control on the spread of infectious diseases.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in neuroscience for more than a century. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is still poorly understood. Here we show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the evolution of brain information-processing capacity. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the evolution of brain information-processing capacity. We also show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the evolution of brain information-processing capacity.

The role of TRAP1 in mitochondria has been the subject of much debate. Here we show that TRAP1 is a critical regulator of the metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a molecular basis for the role of TRAP1 in cancer and suggests that TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. (Read more)

Actin filaments are the major cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family is the major regulator of actin filament disassembly. It is a key player in many cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cytokinesis. However, how it does so in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments in a mechanical context. We find that filament curvature favors severing, while tension has no effect on cofilin binding and weakly enhances severing. We also find that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon cofilin binding. We propose that this ADF/cofilin-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. A consequence of this mechanism is that cross-linked filament networks are severed far more efficiently than nonconnected filaments. Fructose, a common sweetener found in many beverages and processed foods, is a major contributor to the rising epidemic of obesity in the United States. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that fructose may be a stronger trigger of craving and desire for palatable foods than glucose. These findings have implications for the development of strategies to reduce the consumption of fructose. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in the population. Finally, we found that the genetic structure is not only a function of the admixture, but also of the geography, suggesting that the history of Madagascar is still being written. This is a unique study of a unique island.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which has been observed in laboratory experiments but is controversial in the real world. We show that the influence of others’ emotions is not limited to in-person interaction, and that people are influenced by the emotions of others even when they do not see them in person. This work suggests that in-person interaction is not necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work also suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others even when they do not see them in person.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences are modified in many ways, and these modifications can have profound effects on the translation of the mRNA. In this work, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in an mRNA codon can have a profound effect on the translation of the mRNA. We find that the presence of Ψ can promote the low-level synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the reconstituted translation system as well as human cells, and increases the rate of near-cognate Val-tRNAVal reacting on a ΨUU codon. The vast majority of Ψ moieties in mRNAs are found in coding regions, and our study suggests that one consequence of the ribosome encountering Ψ can be to modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This work provides a glimpse into the many ways in which mRNA sequences can be modified and how these modifications can impact protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. We show that higher worthwhile ratings are associated with stronger personal relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, greater prosperity, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, more favorable biomarker profiles, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone or watching television. Longitudinally over a 4-y period, worthwhile ratings predict positive changes in social, economic, health, and behavioral outcomes independently of baseline levels. These findings suggest that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. They also highlight the importance of a sense of purpose in life for health and well-being. Interventions that promote a sense of worthwhile activities may be beneficial for older people. The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a key feature of the evolution of vertebrates in general. We use a model of the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the need to maintain a balance between thermoregulatory and feeding efficiency costs. This model explains the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals and suggests that the evolution of larger body sizes in vertebrates in general is driven by the need to maintain a balance between thermoregulatory and feeding efficiency costs.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature at which rhinovirus replicates most efficiently in the human respiratory tract is unknown. We show that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicate more efficiently at the cool temperature of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We also show that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is dependent on the RIG-I–like receptor signaling pathway. These findings have implications for understanding the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication in the human respiratory tract and for the development of antiviral strategies for the treatment of the common cold. Bacteria use a variety of sensors to detect environmental signals and respond appropriately. Here we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin type IV pili to detect contact with surfaces. This mechanosensory system is mediated by the Chp chemosensory system, a chemotaxis-like system that regulates the production of the second messenger cAMP and transcription of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. The methyl-accepting chemotaxis protein-like chemosensor PilJ directly interacts with the major pilin subunit PilA. Our results thus support a mechanochemical model where a chemosensory system measures the mechanically induced conformational changes in stretched type IV pili. These findings demonstrate that P. aeruginosa not only uses type IV pili for surface-specific twitching motility, but also as a sensor regulating surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This mechanochemical model of surface sensing may be relevant to other bacteria and may have implications for the development of new strategies for controlling bacterial infections. The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still not fully understood. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface water is widespread and that the concentrations of these chemicals are often high enough to cause harm to aquatic life. Our results suggest that the use of pesticides in agriculture is a major threat to the health of global surface water resources. We recommend that governments worldwide implement stricter regulations to protect aquatic ecosystems from the harmful effects of pesticides. We also call for more research on the effects of pesticides on the environment and human health. Only through a better understanding of the risks can we hope to find effective ways to reduce the use of these chemicals.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the world, and the animal reservoir for SARS-CoV-2 is a key area of uncertainty. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in Iowa, USA. We found that the virus was circulating in deer during the peak of the human pandemic, and that the virus was transmitted between deer. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. Our results highlight the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This will be critical to the development of effective strategies to mitigate the spread of the virus. (Less)

The hydropower industry has been building dams in the developing world for decades. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a global problem that needs to be addressed. This paper examines the problems of building large dams in the developing world and proposes solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to the sustained activation of microglia, which are the principal immune cells in the brain. Here, we show that neurons are also capable of mounting an immune response, and that this response is unique to Aβ-burdened neurons. We demonstrate that Aβ-burdened neurons are the primary source of cytokines, which are known to activate microglia and induce the release of inflammatory mediators. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary source of the inflammatory response in AD. This study provides a new perspective on the AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies.

The domestic chicken is today one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still debated. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal assemblage from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the Hellenistic period. We further show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the domestic chicken and its spread throughout the ancient world. (Less)

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein of 370 residues. We find that the folding of the protein is a multistep process. The folding intermediates are distinct and are not the same as the native state. The results suggest that the folding of large proteins is more complex than previously thought. This work adds a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. (Show more)

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the cellular mechanisms that control the levels of these molecules and the factors that influence their decay remain largely unknown. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to remove the cap from 16S rRNA, is also capable of removing the Np4 cap. We demonstrate that RppH preferentially removes Np4-capped RNAs, and that this enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini. These findings suggest that RppH may play a more important role in controlling the levels of Np4-capped RNAs than previously thought.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the immune dysfunction is associated with poor clinical outcome. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore immune function and decrease immunosuppression in sepsis. We found that citrulline, an amino acid derived from arginine, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a new perspective on the role of arginine in the immune system and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for sepsis. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature, such as earthquakes, avalanches, or forest fires, where systems exhibit critical behavior without the need for external control. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity, a power-law distribution of event sizes, and a self-organized critical state. The sandpile model is the first and archetypical model of SOC. In this paper, we study the sandpile model in the continuum limit. We show that the sandpile model exhibits a critical state and a power-law distribution of event sizes. We also show that the sandpile model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Therefore, it is important to understand the effects of strain on its electronic and optical properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and its electronic bandgap can be fully closed. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and its electronic bandgap can be fully opened, by applying tensile strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work also provides a framework for exploring the effects of strain on other materials. This work is expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices and applications.

The role of plant immune peptides in the defense of plants against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis of their antifungal activity is not well understood. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide from the legume Medicago truncatula. This peptide is highly diverse and exhibits potent antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. We show that this peptide binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro and that it binds to the fungal cell wall and penetrates the cell membrane at discrete foci. This peptide is a promising candidate for further development as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive axis is a fundamental system in biology, and it is critical to understanding the evolution of life on Earth. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins become more abundant in sperm after mating, suggesting that the female reproductive tract is a critical site of molecular continuity between males and females. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular basis of reproductive continuity and the evolution of the male–female reproductive axis. (Less)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is critical for hemostasis. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force can be used to switch the conformation of VWF, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the effects of mutations in VWD. The force-switchable mechanism is also consistent with the effects of mutations in other proteins. This work provides a new tool for studying the effects of mutations in proteins of interest. It also provides a mechanism for the effects of force on proteins in the cell.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the viral component of the microbiome, has only recently been studied. This study is the first to use a large number of publicly available metagenomic datasets to assemble a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses. The database is used to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results are used to identify the most important human-associated viruses, and to identify the most important human-associated viral families.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe aerosols and clouds simultaneously. This instrument is expected to be a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This is a significant advance in the field of aerosol–cloud interaction. The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface is important because it is the temperature at which life on Earth exists. The temperature of the surface is also important because it is the temperature at which the chemical reactions that sustain life occur. This study uses a method that has not been used before to determine the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past. The method is based on the thermostability of enzymes that are used in the chemical reactions that sustain life. The results of this study are consistent with the temperature of the surface of the Earth decreasing over geological time.

Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in the cell membrane. They are also the main targets of drugs. Ion channels are activated by opening their pore gates and inactivated by closing their pore gates. The pore gates are located at the intracellular end of the channel and the selectivity filter. The pore gates are the main targets of drugs. We found that the pore gates of the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel are spatially overlapped or colocalized with the selectivity filter’s C-type inactivation gate. The BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and its rates and extents inversely correlate with channel-open probability. The BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings may help us understand the mechanism of K+ channel inactivation and may provide new targets for drug development. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with over 100 million cases and 200,000 deaths each year. The parasite, Plasmodium, enters the human or animal host cell through a process of invasion. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the host cell, which is critical for invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are in a balance of forces, with the parasite providing the energy to overcome a critical energy barrier. This work has implications for the development of new strategies to combat this disease. (Show more)

We also show that diamond can be demetallized, by applying tensile strain, to graphite. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work is expected to advance the understanding of the fundamental physics of diamond and its applications. It will also help in the development of diamond-based devices and sensors. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of low humidity on host response to influenza infection and disease outcome. The brain is thought to build a hierarchical representation of the structure of a sentence, but there is no direct evidence for this. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This suggests that the brain uses a merge operation to build phrases from words. We also show that the merge operation is implemented by multiple regions in the brain, including multiple superior temporal and inferior frontal sites. Finally, we show that the merge operation is best explained by a model of phrase construction, suggesting that the brain uses a bottom-up parser to extract the structure of sentences. Our results provide direct evidence for a neurophysiological implementation of a left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. This is consistent with the idea that the brain is a universal parser.

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. Axin is a dual-functional protein that can be either a scaffold or a phosphatase. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the Wnt signal. This is an important feature that may be used to fine-tune the Wnt pathway in different tissues.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. It contains neurons that project to the ventral tegmental area (VTA), where they inhibit dopamine neurons. Here we show that this circuit is critical for the rapid vigorous eating that occurs in response to stimulation of LH neurons. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to engineer the nitrogen cycle is therefore a key goal in sustainable agriculture. In this work, we have developed a system for the control of nitrogen fixation in a cereal plant. This system is based on the use of a bacterial signal, rhizopine, which is produced by barley plants and allows for the control of nitrogen fixation in the associated bacterium. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to engineer a sustainable nitrogen cycle in agriculture. (Less)

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its deforestation is a global concern. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to reduce deforestation in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the high degree of uncertainty in the estimates. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are made up of cellular tissue and are part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. Instead, it uses the web it makes to listen to the world around it. The spider’s web is a self-manufactured acoustic antenna that is so sensitive that it can hear the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the eardrums of all other animals. The spider can also increase its acoustic sensitivity by outsourcing its ears to its web, which is a unique feature for studying extended and regenerative sensing. The spider’s web provides a unique platform for studying the physics of sound detection and manipulation. It also provides a new way to listen to the world around us.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. Our results indicate that the health benefits of a phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions are comparable to the benefits of the Kyoto Protocol. However, the climate benefits are much larger. The health benefits of a phaseout of all anthropogenic sources are larger than those of the Kyoto Protocol and the Paris Agreement. The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed over 1.5 million lives in the United States alone. The current vaccines are effective, but their high cost limits their global access. We engineered a SARS-CoV-2 receptor-binding domain (RBD) that is well-suited for large-scale manufacturing and has enhanced immunogenicity. This engineered RBD can be presented on a virus-like particle (VLP) to reduce weight loss in hamsters. These results suggest that the engineered RBD can be used in a vaccine to address the global pandemic.

Neuroblastoma is the most common tumor of the neural crest, a group of cells that gives rise to many tissues and organs. In the last years, we have identified mutations in the gene encoding the protooncogene anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) as a cause of neuroblastoma. Here, we show that secreted ALKAL proteins are ligands for ALK and that they are involved in the development of zebrafish neuroblasts. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and their involvement in neural crest development. This work provides a better understanding of the role of ALK in neuroblastoma and opens the way for the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. The emergence of plague as a human pathogen is one of the most dramatic events in human history. The study of ancient genomes has revealed the emergence of plague in the Neolithic, but the diversity of this early form of the pathogen is unknown. Here, we present 17 genomes from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age, which span a period of 7,000 y. Our results show that the Yersinia pestis lineage that gave rise to the plague pandemic in the 4th century CE was already present in Europe and the Near East during the Bronze Age. This suggests that the plague pandemic was not a unique event in human history but rather part of a more continuous process of emergence and adaptation. Our results also reveal the presence of a second form of Y. pestis in Bronze Age Iberia, which is not found in other regions. This suggests that the spread of plague into Europe was not a single event but rather the result of multiple introductions. These data provide a more complete picture of the early history of plague and its relationship to humans and their environments.

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump. We found that HM predicted men’s and women’s support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. HM was also associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia. These findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings also suggest that HM may be a target for intervention to reduce support for men’s and women’s patriarchal dominance. Future work should examine the relationship between HM and men’s and women’s endorsement of other forms of patriarchal dominance, such as patriarchy-promoting religious beliefs.

The agricultural management of grasslands and croplands is a key driver of climate change. In this study, we show that soil health management practices can increase soil organic carbon (SOC) storage in the United States. We also show that the effects of these practices on SOC storage are highly dependent on the soil type and the type of crop grown. Our results highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors associated with spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We then used this framework to systematically identify the highest risk viruses. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting database, SpillOver, is a living, interactive database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work is a first step toward a more comprehensive understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts animals, but the mechanisms that underlie its production are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify the enzymes responsible for the production of this compound and demonstrate that the same three enzymatic activities are necessary for the production of a red pigment in two other plants visited by vertebrates. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait that is likely to be favored by natural selection. This work provides a better understanding of the mechanisms that underlie the evolution of nectar color and its role in attracting pollinators.

The history of Europe is marked by a complex interplay of migration and admixture processes. However, the population-level history of the continent during the period between the migrations of the Germanic peoples and the arrival of the Romans is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 6th centuries AD. Our results indicate that these women had a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a newly identified pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The global spread of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens is a global health concern. The current study describes the use of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to identify the regional pathogen landscape and the risk factors associated with undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. The results suggest that mNGS is a feasible and cost-effective approach for pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study provides a model for mNGS-based pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. This model can be applied to other regions with similar challenges. The results also highlight the importance of vector control and zoonotic disease surveillance in the global fight against emerging pathogens. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and its role in eukaryotic DNA replication. The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in biology. In this paper, we describe the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA. This work represents a major step toward the goal of creating a functional RNA-based cell in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to measure the physical changes in any city over time. We hope that our method will be useful to urban researchers and practitioners. The code and data are available at https://github.com/yuhang-liu/neighborhood-improvement.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical patients with COVID-19 are analyzed, and the immune characteristics of patients with severe and critical COVID-19 are identified. The pathogenic T cells and inflammatory monocytes with large amount of interleukin 6 secreting may incite the inflammatory storm, which may potentially be curbed through monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-6 pathways. Tocilizumab is an effective treatment to reduce mortality. The results provide a reference for the clinical treatment of severe and critical patients with COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but it is also a highly toxic metal. The existence of a fungal metal homeostasis system that is not based on the use of a copper-binding natural product is surprising. The existence of a fungal metal homeostasis system that is not based on the use of a metal-binding natural product is surprising. The formation of silica-rich minerals in a sedimentary environment is a rare occurrence on Earth. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Mars is a significant discovery.
