Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals in the temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that this change is not uniform across the Northern Hemisphere. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees are not uniform across the region, and that this is likely to change in the future. Our findings can inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of Th17 cells are not well understood. Here we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which retains a Th17 phenotype and the other of which transitions to a Th1-like phenotype. The Th1-like cells are required for the development of colitis, and they require the expression of both the transcription factors T-bet and Stat4. Th17 cells can also provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease. Understanding the mechanisms that control the development of Th17 cells may lead to the development of new therapies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, but also by genetic risk factors, such as expansion of a noncoding RNA. The disease is also associated with environmental factors, such as exposure to toxic metals. The disease is fatal, and there are no treatments that can slow or stop the disease. We now report a method to rapidly produce induced astrocytes from living ALS patients. These cells can be used to model the disease, identify treatments, and ultimately lead to the development of new therapies. This is a major advance in ALS research.

The role of the microbiome in vector-borne disease transmission is an emerging area of research. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the tick Ixodes scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the transmission of Anaplasma. We demonstrate that IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which a human pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work also highlights the potential for the use of arthropod antibacterial proteins as a new class of vector-targeted therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of vertebrates. However, the origin of the modern avian body plan is still a matter of debate. Here, we describe a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery increases the known diversity of early members of the short-tailed bird group and adds important information about the origin of the modern avian body plan.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand it in its entirety. However, it is possible to understand the main features of the climate system by focusing on the most important processes. In this paper, we show that the water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color in response to external stimuli. The most common color change is the green-to-blue color shift of many anurans (frogs and toads) in the presence of water. This phenomenon is called chlorosis. We show that the occurrence of high biliverdin in anurans has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of serpin family proteins that bind biliverdin. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis and a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily. Additionally, we describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and metastasis. We report that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. We show that ALKBH5 is required for the maintenance of breast cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and metastasis. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, but the source of the parchment used to make them has been a long-standing mystery. Here, we report a method that allows the source of the parchment to be identified without the need to open the manuscript. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to generate an electrostatic charge on the parchment surface, which is then analyzed by mass spectrometry. The method is noninvasive and can be used on manuscripts in the public domain. The results suggest that the source of the parchment was not the result of a deliberate policy of using abortive or newborn animals. Instead, the results suggest that the production process allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This process may have been possible because of the use of a simple and inexpensive process for the production of parchment. (Show more)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is unknown, but the timing of the event, the carbon cycle disruption, and the recovery dynamics depend on a precise age model. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a member of the retinoic acid-related orphan receptors (RORs) family, which is involved in various biological processes, such as cancer, metabolism, and circadian rhythm. However, the role of RORα in the intestinal epithelium is still unclear. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. Together, we demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated

The spike glycoprotein of the novel coronavirus that causes COVID-19 is a major target for vaccine development. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the human receptor ACE2, bound in the same way as the natural receptor for SARS-CoV. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation that may facilitate binding to the receptor. This may be important for the spread of the virus.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in 2020, the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction at age 65 y for the total US population. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are also the key to understanding the chemistry of compounds. In this paper, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure. This is a new and unexpected result, which has important implications for chemistry.

Fire is a key ecosystem process, but its effects on climate are poorly understood. We show that changes in fire activity, driven by human demography, can have a significant impact on the global carbon cycle. We find that, although uncertainty is large, changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to better understand the effects of fire on climate.

The gut microbiota is a critical component of the health of many animals, but the mechanisms by which they interact are largely unknown. Here, we show that the symbiotic relationship between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri is regulated by the host’s provision of a single glycan. We show that the glycan is provided only at night, when the squid is in the dark phase, and that it is required for the persistence of the symbiont. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is able to acidify the crypts where the symbiont lives, thereby enhancing its capacity to produce bioluminescence. This work suggests that the provision of specific nutrients may be a common mechanism for regulating the activities of the gut microbiota in animals. This could have important implications for the health of animals and the functioning of ecosystems. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous and increasingly important for understanding human behavior and social processes. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as sequences of topics. This method is based on advances in theoretical machine learning and can be applied to a wide range of domains. We illustrate the method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. It is generally assumed that the disease was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. However, this assumption is based on a single hypothesis, which has not been tested. We show that the disease was introduced repeatedly into European harbors, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the disease was not introduced into Europe from a single source, but rather from multiple sources, which were separated by a delay of 15 y. This delay is consistent with the time required for the bacterium to travel from Asia to Europe. Our results provide evidence for the existence of multiple plague reservoirs in Asia, which were repeatedly reintroduced into Europe. This suggests that the Black Death was not a single event, but rather a series of events.

Asteroids are a common species of the Northeast Pacific Coast. In recent years, they have been observed to undergo mass mortality events, which are associated with a sea-star wasting disease. We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus. We also show that the virus is present in the environment and in the tissues of the affected asteroids. This suggests that the virus is spread by the environment and that it has been present on the Pacific Coast for at least 72 y.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common type of blood cancer, and the prognosis is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study provides a proof of principle for the use of antibody-based therapies in AML. This approach could be extended to other

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in the population. This study provides a new perspective on the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. It also provides a new tool to study the history of other island populations. View Full-Text

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While small RNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and increases dehydrogenase activity. We found that the RNA also interacts with two other enzymes and that the interaction with glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase is required for the RNA to repress carbon utilization genes. The RNA and protein compete for binding to the same sites on the two genes. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has a regulatory role and a regulatory role that competes with a second regulatory role.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Less)

Crop experts are the backbone of the agricultural sector, and their knowledge is critical for the management of agricultural production. However, the complexity of the information they provide, and the large number of experts involved, makes it difficult to use their knowledge in a quantitative way. We show that the Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is conducted by a large number of experts across the US, can be used to provide a quantitative measure of crop status. We show that this measure is robust, stable, and can be used to provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of using the knowledge of large numbers of experts to provide early warnings of crop anomalies and to improve the accuracy of agricultural forecasts. This can be extended to other crops and countries.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that memory is supported by intrinsic plasticity in neuronal networks. We show that the activity of a small number of neurons can be used to write information into a set of dynamic variables that control the rate of adaptation. These variables are then used to read back information into the active membrane state for processing. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We believe that this is a biologically plausible mechanism for memory and that it may be relevant to the processing of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most fundamental events in the evolution of life. It is also one of the most difficult to model, as it involves the simultaneous loss of a large number of genes and the acquisition of a new lifestyle. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle, rather than the loss of photosynthesis, is the key event that relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the impact of climate change on water security. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for water managers and policy makers in SSA and beyond. It also highlights the importance of reducing greenhouse gas emissions to avoid the most severe droughts in the future. View Full-Text

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they are formed are still not fully understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this quasicrystal, which was formed in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, is a testament to the power of science to reveal the history of our planet.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, and it is powered by light, which is captured by chlorophyll. The chlorophyll pigments are modified tetrapyrroles, and the formation of the fifth ring, the isocyclic ring, is the most important reaction in this process. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, which have remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This paper describes the discovery of a third class of the enzyme, which is required for oxygenic photosynthesis.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis. Neuroinflammation is also a major feature of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a model of multiple sclerosis. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 is required for neuroinflammation in EAE. We found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages is required for the early stage of EAE, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes is required for the later stage of EAE. We also found that ASK1 in astrocytes is required for the generation and maintenance of disease. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in astrocytes is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroinflammation-related diseases. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to the influence of human activities. Our results suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that created the 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a broad spectrum of symptoms. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. Mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. This work is the first to our knowledge to examine the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. It is also the first to our knowledge to examine the extent to which individual differences in reaction to news content may be related to personality. Results suggest that, on average, people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. They also suggest that individual differences in reaction to news content may be related to personality. These findings may help explain the prevalence of negative news content around the world. They may also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of intracellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 (p.R304W) associated with Stormorken syndrome, and in ORAI1 (p.P245L), associated with a Stormorken-like syndrome of congenital miosis and tubular aggregate myopathy but without hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. In this study, we use a fluorescently tagged form of the polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to study the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We demonstrate that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, indicating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of spreading and the propagation of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. They also provide a platform for studying the mechanisms of spreading in other neurodegenerative diseases. This could lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. By selectively inhibiting the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection, MTX inhibited the antiviral responses of the host and facilitated viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. We believe that this study will help to improve our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats and provide a deeper insight into the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study will also help to improve our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spill

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus a metabolic target. In this study, we show that the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a metabolic target of cancer. We identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it blocks cancer cell growth in vitro and in vivo. We also show that SHMT is a metabolic target of B-cell lymphoma, and that this cancer is uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, we have identified a metabolic deficiency of a cancer type, and a targetable metabolic deficiency of a cancer type. This work is a step toward the development of a metabolic drug for cancer.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This may be a general phenomenon in neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The results are expected to have broad implications for the development of atom-based quantum technologies. The 2D photonic crystal system is a promising platform for many-body physics with neutral atoms. The Cretaceous is a key time in the history of life, with the origin of many major groups of organisms. The Cretaceous is also a time of great interest for the origin of plants, with many groups of plants diversifying in this period. The Cretaceous is also a time of great interest for the origin of flowering plants, with the origin of the group in the Cretaceous being a major hypothesis. Here we present a detailed study of a Cretaceous flowering plant, Montsechia, and show that it is sister to Ceratophyllum, a group of plants that are important in the history of flowering plants.

Parvoviruses are small, nonenveloped, single-stranded DNA viruses that are ubiquitous in nature. They are known to cause a number of diseases, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The evolution of parvoviruses has been studied for a long time, but the rate of evolution of the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is still debated. Here we present 10 ancient parvovirus genomes from humans that lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Less)

Sea level is rising around the world. This rise is due to a combination of natural processes and human activities. The rate of sea level rise is accelerating. The rate of rise is also increasing. These trends are due to the thermal expansion of the oceans and the melting of glaciers and ice sheets. The rate of sea level rise is a key indicator of climate change and its impact on coastal areas.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain is increasing with age, but that the increase is less steep for those with less education. This suggests that the erosion of working-class life is associated with a rise in pain.

The structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is a key element in understanding enzyme function. However, the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is difficult to determine experimentally. Here, we show how NMR-assisted crystallography can be used to determine the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex. This approach provides a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the enzyme–substrate complex, including the location of the substrate hydroxyl leaving group, which is critical for understanding the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This detailed picture of the enzyme–substrate complex is key to understanding the reaction mechanism.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe emerging coronavirus infection that has caused a high mortality rate. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the current standard of care is supportive care. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS. It may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance, as there is a pressing need for effective antiviral treatments for these infections. The availability of such treatments would also help to reduce the spread of these diseases.

The gut microbiota of animals is a major component of the immune system, and its composition is known to change in response to environmental cues. However, the mechanisms by which the microbiota is regulated are not well understood. Here, we show that the symbiotic bacterium of the squid Euprymna scolopes, which lives in the crypts of the host, is required to maintain the host immune cells in the crypts. We also show that the squid regulates the provision of a specific glycan to the symbiont, which is required for the catabolism of the glycan by the symbiont. This regulation of the symbiont is likely to be a common mechanism used by animals to control the composition of their gut microbiota. This mechanism may be important for the health of the host and the microbiota. (Show more)

Alkylated DNA lesions, induced by both exogenous chemical agents and endogenous metabolites, are major contributors to mutagenesis and transcriptional stalling. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We observed distinct pol II stalling profiles for the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions. Intriguingly, pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. Assessment for the impact of the EtdT lesions on individual fidelity checkpoints provided further mechanistic insights, where the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand how MERS-CoV infects human cells, we introduced mutations that blocked the first two steps of virus entry. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that the first two steps of virus entry are critical for MERS-CoV infection of human cells, and may be important determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large share of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing these emissions. However, the food system is also a major contributor to obesity and other health problems. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering operation can have a large impact on sales. This suggests that it may be possible to make a significant contribution to both environmental and health goals by altering the physical environment in which people make their food choices. The results also suggest that it may be possible to achieve this without compromising other goals, such as increasing overall sales. This has important implications for the design of interventions to promote more sustainable diets. (Less)

The cell surface is the interface between the cell and its environment. It is a dynamic and complex system, and is the site of many important biological processes. Here we use a combination of mass spectrometry and isotope-coded affinity tag technology to study the surface proteome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most common oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. We also complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics enabled by a recently developed technique called activated ion electron transfer dissociation. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the role of the cell surface in cancer development and progression. This work also provides a resource for the cancer research community to study the surfaceome of their own cancer cell lines.

The 2020 presidential election is likely to be the first in which a significant number of voters will cast ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on the 2020 election. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Here, we report the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This dimerization interface is unique to SARS-CoV-2 and may be important for immune evasion and evasion of the host innate immune system. This work provides a molecular basis for understanding the unique properties of the SARS-CoV-2 virus and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. Hypoxia is a common condition in the brain, and it is known to cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1, which triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies for this condition. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The problem is of great importance because the size of the data sets and the sophistication of the statistical methods used to analyze them are increasing rapidly.

Endothelial cells (ECs) are the most abundant cell type in the blood vessels, and their dysfunction is a major cause of many diseases. Therefore, the generation of ECs is a promising approach for treating many diseases. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, transduced ETV2 elicits expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for treating many diseases. (Show more)

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important drivers of cancer. Here, we show that zebrafish pigment development is mediated by augmentor ligands and Ltk. Augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized type of photoreceptor that is present in the skin and the eye of adult zebrafish. We demonstrate that augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores in the skin and the eye of adult zebrafish. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a new perspective on the role of ligand-activated RTKs in development and cancer. It also provides a model system for studying the function of orphan RTKs in the zebrafish. Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well known, the underlying mechanisms of insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are still unclear. Herein, we found that STING is required for β-cell function and GSIS. STING deficiency in β-cells impaired GSIS, which is a major cause of T2D. Our study provides a new perspective for the treatment of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the most important pathogens of humans and animals. They are divided into two major groups, the human and avian influenza viruses, which are distinguished by their host species of origin. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which is a unique feature of this virus family. The packaging of the viral genome is a complex process, and the details of the molecular interactions involved in the packaging of the viral genome are unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza virus. We show that this interaction is required for optimal viral replication and that it favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results provide insights into the molecular details of the packaging of the influenza A virus genome. These findings might be useful for the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Atherosclerotic lesions are the result of a complex interplay between the local hemodynamic environment and the local phenotype of the endothelial cells (ECs). The focal nature of atherosclerotic lesions suggests an important role of local hemodynamic environment. Recent studies have demonstrated significant roles of Yes-associated protein (YAP) and transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in mediating mechanotransduction and vascular homeostasis. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. This work is relevant to many regions of the world where human activities are increasing the risk of wildfires. (Abridged)

We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Natural repellents are a promising alternative to chemical pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of insect–plant interaction. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also show that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. In the case of favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, we predict a dose of 150 mg/kg given twice a day initiated at the time of infection can reduce the peak median viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median viral load by ∼2 d. Coral reefs are among the most diverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including climate change. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is a direct consequence of the altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This process is driven by the increased metabolic energy demand of the coral host, which is compensated by the catabolism of amino acids. The resulting shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont subsequently promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. This study provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. In this study, we show that intestinal tumors can alter the composition of the intestinal microbiome, leading to a dysbiotic microbiome and a regenerative response. This leads to a further increase in tumor burden, which in turn triggers a regenerative response. We propose that this feedback loop is a general mechanism that can be used to control the activity of the JNK pathway. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients relapse. In this study, we found that the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is expressed in a subset of breast cancer cells, and that ROR1 expression is increased in response to chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 expression is associated with the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reestablish tumors in mice. Finally, we found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with a humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab and chemotherapy was more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is marked by a unique, nearly synchronous acceleration in ice core records of climate and greenhouse gases. We show that this event is linked to a volcanic eruption series, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a change in Southern Hemisphere climate.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security and biodiversity conservation. We find that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels, and that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people. Our map of riverine fisheries can be used to identify regions where inland fisheries are most important for food security and biodiversity conservation. We also show that the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. For achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate neurons is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In mammals, this ability is lost after early development, and the few remaining species that retain the ability to regenerate neurons have a limited capacity for repair. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is the primary pathway known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery opens up the possibility that this form of regeneration may be more broadly conserved than previously thought. Moreover, this study provides a framework for understanding the molecular control of regeneration in the adult nervous system.

Recombination is a fundamental process in biology, and its rate is a key factor in determining the structure of genomes. In this study, we use a population of wild flowers to map the locations of recombination events in a flowering plant. We find that recombination occurs more frequently in the promoter regions of genes than in the coding regions, and that recombination is more likely to terminate in the coding regions of genes than in the introns. These results suggest that the process of recombination is conserved in plants and animals.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in functional connectivity that are used to identify networks of functionally related brain regions. However, the brain is also a metabolic system, with fluctuations in total activity that are used to identify networks of functionally related metabolically active brain regions. Here, we show that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects is topologically similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic fluctuations in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease patients. Network deactivation was observed in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease patients, and this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Time-course comparisons of DMN loss in longitudinal resting metabolic scans from Parkinson’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease patients illustrated that significant reductions appeared later for Parkinson’s disease, in parallel with the development of cognitive dysfunction. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. Metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is the target of many antiviral proteins. Here we show that yeast cells contain a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group. We find that NAD-mRNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. NAD-mRNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD-RNA is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. This finding suggests that NAD-RNA could modulate mRNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. The discovery of NAD-RNA in yeast opens the possibility that this modification is widespread in eukaryotes.

The epigenetic regulation of gene expression is a key mechanism for the maintenance of metabolic memory. We studied the epigenetic DNA-methylation (DNA-me) profile of whole blood (WB) and monocytes (Monos) from people with diabetes during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. We found that DNA-me alterations at specific loci in WB and Monos are associated with glycemia for several years during the EDIC Study. In vitro, high glucose induced similar persistent hypomethylation at thioredoxin-interacting protein (TXNIP) in cultured THP1 Monos. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory and suggest that TXNIP may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of diabetes complications. Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. It is characterized by the absence of estrogen, progesterone, and human epidermal growth factor 2 receptors. TNBC is associated with poor prognosis and has a high rate of recurrence. We show that the expression of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is associated with poor prognosis in TNBC patients. We also show that FSIP1 is required for the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells. FSIP1 deficiency promotes autophagy, enhances AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreases mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high prevalence and a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the development of psychological symptoms. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the development of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

Tomato fruit are among the most popular fruits in the world, and the quality of their flavor is of great importance to consumers. The flavor of tomato fruit is largely determined by the composition of their volatile chemical profile, which is generated by a complex set of biochemical reactions. This work identifies a gene essential for the production of a subset of these volatile compounds, and provides a framework for understanding the biosynthesis of these compounds in tomato fruit. This work also provides a model for understanding the biosynthesis of a class of compounds in other species of the tomato clade.

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these two factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result is driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. First, more diverse communities have a greater chance of including species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain productivity as temperatures shift from ambient conditions. Second, we found a pronounced increase in the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions played a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. This is a key finding for understanding the impacts of climate change on the functioning of ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It is thought to encode the spatial layout of the environment, but the organization of its neurons is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to encode the spatial layout of the environment, are strongly coupled among themselves but have weaker links to other cell types. These data suggest that grid cells might be largely distinct from those of other cell types and that grid cells exhibit strong coupling among themselves but weaker links to other cell types. This study provides a new method for studying the organization of neurons in the brain. It also provides a framework for understanding how the brain encodes and processes information.

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a number of genes and environmental cues. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing cells of the substantia nigra. The disease is associated with a loss of dopamine-containing neurons and a reduction in the dopamine-releasing system. The mechanisms that cause this loss are not fully understood. Here we show that the dopamine-producing neurons are connected to other brain regions and to other parts of the dopamine-releasing system. We also show that the dopamine-producing neurons are connected to other parts of the dopamine-releasing system. This suggests that the dopamine-releasing system is more complex than previously thought and that it is important to understand the connections between the dopamine-producing neurons and other parts of the system.

We all have a sense of when we feel connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for setting the heart rate, and their function is critical for maintaining a normal heart rate. However, the mechanisms that govern SAN function are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN function. We found that STIM1 is highly expressed in SANCs and is required for the maintenance of SAN function. Our results reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms that govern SAN function and may lead to the development of new therapies for heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well established. In this study, we found that Si pretreatment increased rice resistance against the rice leaffolder in wild-type plants but not in RNAi lines that were silenced for allene oxide synthase (OsAOS) and CORONATINE INSENSITIVE1 (OsCOI1), which are active in jasmonate (JA) biosynthesis and perception, respectively. We also found that Si pretreatment promoted Si accumulation and enhanced defense responses in leaves of rice plants after insect attack. These results suggest a strong interaction between Si and JA in defense against insect herbivores involving priming of JA-mediated defense responses by Si and the promotion of Si accumulation by JA. These findings provide insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may have implications for the use of Si in agriculture. (Less)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism and that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that memory is supported by intrinsic plasticity in neuronal networks. We show that the activity of a small number of neurons can be used to write information into a set of dynamic variables that control the rate of adaptation. These variables are then used to read back information into the active membrane state for processing. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We believe that this is a biologically plausible mechanism for memory and that it may be relevant to the processing of language.

Plants are the most important source of food and medicine for the human race. However, they are difficult to genetically modify, and the delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge. Here, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are the key design parameters for the delivery of siRNAs to plants. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the development of plant-based therapeutics and biotechnologies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes worldwide, but the relative importance of point and nonpoint sources of nutrients is poorly understood. We show that the majority of the nutrients delivered to Lake Michigan by its tributaries are from small watersheds. These findings have important implications for the management of coastal eutrophication, as they suggest that small tributaries may be a major source of nutrients to nearshore areas. Our results also highlight the need to better understand the role of small watersheds in coastal eutrophication, as they are often overlooked in current management efforts. Our findings suggest that small watersheds may be a major source of coastal eutrophication, and thus, a major target for future management efforts.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is difficult to access. We find that the system is biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the existence of a large-scale steady state requires that the initial conditions be extremely fine-tuned.

The mechanisms by which the NMDA-receptor antibody causes seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that the NMDA-receptor antibody changes the intrinsic properties of the cortex, which in turn changes the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. This predisposes brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities, which can lead to seizures. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the mechanisms of seizure induction in NMDA-receptor encephalitis. They also suggest that the same mechanisms may be involved in other autoimmune epilepsies. This may have implications for the treatment of these conditions.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was linked to a global warming and an injection of organic matter into the ocean. We also show that this event was linked to an increase in the strength of the thermohaline circulation and nutrient fluxes, which may have led to a biodiversity nadir. These results have implications for our understanding of the history of abrupt climate change and the potential for future abrupt climate change.

The palm oil industry is the largest consumer of deforestation-prone tropical peatlands in the world. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the leading certification body for palm oil, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase only certified palm oil. We show that certification is associated with a 33% reduction in deforestation in oil palm plantations in Indonesia. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the importance of certification in forested regions and the need for certification to be tightly linked to robust monitoring. These findings are relevant to other commodities and certification schemes. (Abridged)

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit complex that is involved in the last steps of exocytosis. It is essential to organisms across kingdoms, including plants and humans. However, the molecular mechanism of the exocyst complex and its regulation are not fully understood. Here, we discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental aspect of animal biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of study in developmental biology. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, but in others, sex is determined by multiple loci. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple loci on secondary sexual characteristics in a species with multiple sex determination alleles. We find that multiple loci can produce a modular system of sexual polymorphism, which can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination alleles in populations. This work also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics in species with multiple sex determination alleles.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct but related insults: accumulation of the lipid-soluble photoproduct of vitamin A, bisretinoids, and light-induced oxidation of these compounds. We show that the intracellular level of iron impacts the retina. In mice treated with the iron chelator deferiprone, the levels of iron in the retina were reduced, and the levels of bisretinoids were elevated. In contrast, mice with increased levels of iron in retinal pigment epithelial cells exhibited reduced levels of bisretinoids. These findings suggest that iron levels impact the retina and that the levels of iron in the retina may be important in the regulation of bisretinoid levels. This work provides a foundation for future studies on the role of iron in the retina. (Read more)

Siphonophores are a group of pelagic colonial cnidarians that use tentilla (tentacle side branches armed with nematocysts) exclusively for prey capture. This is a remarkable specialization, and one that has been considered a dead end for evolutionary change. Here we show that siphonophores are highly specialized, and that they can evolve into generalists. We also show that the evolution of siphonophore tentilla is strongly linked to prey type, and that this is associated with the evolution of the tentilla and nematocysts. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also help build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the modern human hand and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand in the context of the broader hominin fossil record. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. We show that this inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and that it is particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition in cancer cells, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a rationale for the use of SHMT inhibitors in the treatment of cancer, and a rationale for the use of glycine import inhibitors in the treatment of DLBCL. It also provides a framework for the design of new small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT. The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. In this study, we show that deforestation is having a negative impact on people’s diets in rural Tanzania. We found that deforestation led to a reduction in fruit and vegetable consumption and thus vitamin A adequacy of diets. Conversely, we found that forest fragmentation led to an increase in fruit and vegetable consumption and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. We hope that this study will encourage policy makers to consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets and nutrition security. (Less)

The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of agriculture, allowing for expansion of the cultivated area and higher yields. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis calls for a rethinking of the role of sauropods
